reviewText: TORNADO! (1996, 90 minutes, Hallmark Films) is one hell of a cheap production. In spite of what appeared to be some star power--Bruce Campbell in a rare dramatic role and Ernie Hudson--it flops badly. Aired the same year the fantasticTwisterpremiered (see my review) it was a pathetic attempt to steal all the ideas and some of the plots from TWISTER. (Actually who can blame Hallmark for stealing: TWISTER was an instant classic not onyl because of its important message but also because no film like it had ever been tried.)There ... that is pretty much it.I absolutely must address the appearance of Bruce Campbell in this cheapo movie. Here he plays a Texan farmer, a meteorology Ph.D. washout who chases storms. While doing his stints on both "Xena: Warrior Princess" and the original "Ellen De Generes Show", and having shot to fame years earlier inArmy of Darkness(in fact he got his start in the EVIL DEAD movies), Campbell was still unquantifiable.All I can say is the man CANNOT act. Funny though he may be, he couldn't act his way out of a wet paper sack. His appearance in this must simply have been a work-a-day job for him since he was mostly a TV actor back then. Yet in this film they don't know what to do with him either. Giving him a pal named Xena, whom he mentions a couple of times, didn't help this film's dramatic cause.The only honest-to-goodness talent on display here was courtesy of that craggy ole cowboy actor, L. Q. Jones, who plays Campbell's grandfather. In fact, the only impressive scene in this film is near the end, involving only Jones in the scene--which I will not spoil. This thing was shot in and around Austin, so I can't complain that they shot in Canada.But they might as well have done. Anyway, I give stars for the effort, for old Jones, and for the odd little title cards at the end:NOAA gives stats of tornadoes from 1961-1990, which are seemingly low, but this film says America is hit with 1,000 a year (that was as of 1996). What really made my eyes bug was the end-title-card admonition about global warming causing more and more tornadoes each year.Back in the 1990s you never heard anyone talk about global warming, and they never even alluded to the concept in TWISTER. In fact, my research only shows averages, and I got an average of 30 tornadoes per year in America, data direct from NOAA.Unless you have some Godforsaken reason to want this, I'd skip it and buy TWISTER instead. And add to that list the absolutely stunning nonfiction book about America's meteorological history, concentrating on tornadoes and chasers:Storm Kings: The Untold History of America's First Tornado Chasers(see my review).
summary: "We're all road kill ... ", or, we will be if we ever do this kind of shameless copying again!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Amazing how Noel Hesseck's direction could make a tornado seem so insignificant.  With little special effects of any note, this Twister wannabe suffers from flat, laconic performances, most notably Bruce Campbell and Ernie Hudson.  Even L.Q. Jones seems winded and lifeless.  An obvious made for TV soapie, that never shows the tornado at its worst.Rent don't buy.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This "Twister" knock-off doesn't really offer much as everyone's favorite ghoul-killer plays it straight, chases storms, and seeks a little romance.  It is great to watch Campbell in something other than a supporting role, but this is a TV cheapie.  On the plus side is a strong supporting cast that includes Ernie Hudson (as Campbell's mentor).The DVD image is full-screen and nothing to write home about.  There are no extras.So, I guess this one is for people who love Ash, couldn't watch "Twister" because of some dislike for Helen Hunt, or just buy anything with a special effect.  Now when will "Atomic Twister" get released?
Title: N/A

reviewText: This movie was so horribly bad that it wasn't even funny. A huge tornado goes through this town and supposedly rips the town to shreds. The damage? Just a bunch of stuff put in the middle of the street in nice neat piles. NO trees damaged, no pavement ripped up, no houses damaged, and no telephone poles pulled over. The worst part was that there no visible serious injuries. Sad.The so called tornado scenes look like they were made with an Etche Sketch. The aftermath scenes were done with a dump truck and a bulldozer. The "Damaged" property was lying in the middle of the street looking like it had been looted out of the remains of a burned out goodwill store.The worst part to me though had to be the scene in which they are standing next to their truck, in the middle of a tornado! I've had a tornado go over my house once.  A tornado is not like a hurricane, where the eye is all calm. With all the debris that a tornado picks up you'd never even get close to the middle of one in the first place. You'd be picked up and thrown around before you're even close middle. There isn't one chance in a billion that you'd drive into a tornado like a fog bank.I think that the fact that they were able to communicate, and walk around inside the "Cone Of Silence", was the biggest joke of all. That shoulda been the title of this horidly bad. And they wonder why many directors keep their set closed to everyone and reveal only a limited amount of the plot. This was obviously a rip-off of "Twister". A cheap, no frills version that was hastily put together to beat Twister to the screen.
summary: Beat Twister, but only carried out a sucker punch.
Title: N/A
